Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Real Estate Speculation and its Impact on Agricultural Access to Water Resources in Contexts of Rapid Urbanization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: In the past three decades, residential real estate markets have undergone significant growth, consonant with the shift from industrial production to financial markets as a principle locus of investment. Residential real estate in particular has become more common, accelerating patterns of land speculation and urbanization in areas undergoing agricultural decline. The socio-ecological effects of these transformations are vast and include processes such as the displacement and segregation of rural populations, livelihood change and work precaritization, deforestation, water privatization, and increases in climate vulnerability. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical data collection and analysis, this doctoral dissertation project provides a scientific analysis of the economic and political practices driving these processes of landscape transformation as well as the experiences of rural communities in areas impacted by rapid urbanization.<br/><br/>This doctoral dissertation research project examines the relationship between real estate speculation and water resource access among agricultural producers in a context of rapid urbanization. It asks three questions about the processes of land speculation and real estate development in rural areas: (1) How have different rural communities experienced the pressures for urbanization and the process of deruralization implied by it? (2) Which are the main groups acquiring residential property in the area and what are the main uses assigned to those properties? (3) What are the rationalities of governmental officials in prioritizing the urbanization of water supply promoted by real estate actors? To answer these questions the doctoral student will analyze the histories of two former agricultural production properties which have been targeted as residential development sites. The researcher will also conduct archival research, oral histories and semi-structured with residents, state officials, developers, urban planners, and other relevant groups. These histories will contribute to scientific understanding about the relationship between rapid urbanization and the financialization of real estate markets, and to what extent human-environment relations are defined by the growth of global financial markets.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the past three decades, residential real estate markets have undergone significant growth across the world. This expansion is connected to a shift in the patterns of capital accumulation which have gone from industrial production and trade toward finance. In such process, residential real estate has become a key mechanism of accumulation as it allows investors to extract value from mortgage payments, rent or property sales. As these practices have become more common, they have accelerated patterns of land speculation and urbanization in areas undergoing agrarian decline, particularly in the Global South. There, the socio-ecological effects of these transformations are vast and include processes like the displacement and segregation of rural populations, livelihood change and work precaritization, deforestation, water privatization and increases in climate vulnerability.

This project looks at the territorial dynamics of rapid urbanization in Nuevo Cuscatl?n, El Salvador, a small town located on the outskirts of San Salvador, whose landscape is undergoing a drastic transformation from a rural environment, characterized by large coffee estates and small peasant communities, to a suburban landscape full of luxurious gated neighborhoods. Through a combination ethnographic and archival research methods, the project carried out a close examination of forms of dispossession and the transformation of ecological relations implied by the building of real estate projects. Particularly, it examines at the human relations mediating such processes. There are three main findings which resulted after a 12-month period of data gathering and analysis:

The first finding is that the dispossession driven by real estate development in Nuevo Cuscatl?n relies heavily on the highly unequal and hierarchical legacies of the oligarchic coffee economy in El Salvador. This was observed in two particular features: (1) real estate actors?  reliance on their connections to local business and political elites in the acquisition of land, building permits, zoning changes and water service contracts; and (2) the exploitation of the rural population?s dependence  on big landowners for housing and water access. Through reconstructions of recent events facilitated by testimonies and documents, I found that residents?/the population?s dependence on big estates and landowners are often manipulated by real estate developers and state officials through ?compensation? projects in which rural communities are forced to accept real estate projects in order to access basic public provisions, like water supply or housing.

A second major finding of the project is the fact that the dispossession process driven by real estate in areas like Nuevo Cuscatl?n cannot be reduced to mere land or water grabbing, but  is also a dispossession of rural communities? access to the forest, an ecosystem where communities are embedded in complex lifeways that shape their livelihoods and identities. Such complexity, however, is rendered invisible by State practices and discourses which reduce rural communities to mere vulnerable populations waiting to be employed in some type of industry.

A third major finding of the project is the propensity of real estate to be integrated into authoritarian populist projects and the implications of this for rural ecologies. Through the examination of president Nayib Bukele?s actions when he was mayor of the town between 2012 and 2015, I found that there are important elements of mutual reinforcement between real estate owners and local government officials which favor the emergence of a populist phenomenon. This reinforcement comes mainly from populist leader?s desire to capture people?s imagination through urbanization, which in many ways provides the incentives for officials to flexibly issue   building permits and other things, like water concessions. On the flipside, while real estate developers benefit from government officials flexible issuing of building permits and water concessions, populist leaders, like Bukele, benefit not only from the high-impact visuals from real estate but also from the financial resources its concessions provide. The symbiotic relationship between real estate and populist leaders has severe consequences for the environment and rural communities since dealings between both  often involve rights over the use of land, water and nature in a broad sense. In the case of Nuevo Cuscatl?n, this relationship accelerated ecological devastation.
